P070547.project_name: Groundwater and Drought Management in SADC Project

keywords.cdata: agricultural chemicals, aquifers, arid areas, Arid Lands, arid regions, Basin Commission, Basin Initiative, basin level, Basin Organizations, boreholes, capacity building, civil society, Climate data, climatic conditions, climatic variability, community involvement, conjunctive use, consensus building, decision making, Diagnostic Analysis, domestic water, domestic water supply, drinking water, DROUGHT, drought conditions, DROUGHT MANAGEMENT, drought management strategies, droughts, environmental benefits, Environmental Management, Environmental Protection, exotic species, fishing, flood protection, food production, food security, Ground Water, ground water management, GROUNDWATER, Groundwater Management, groundwater resources, groundwater users, groundwaters, integrated water resources management, international aquifers, international river basins, International waters, irrigated agriculture, land degradation, Land Rehabilitation, land use, land use practices, livestock, local communities, management, pollution, power generation, programs, Project management, rainfall, riparian, riparian countries, riparian states, River Basin, rivers, stakeholder involvement, transboundary resources, transboundary water resource management, water conservation, Water Policy, water pricing, Water resource, Water resource management, Water Resources Development, Water Resources Management, water scarcity, Water Sector, water security, water supply, water use, wetlands, wildlife

project_abstract.cdata: The objective of the Southern African Development Community (SADC): Groundwater and Drought Management Project is the development of a SADC regional strategic approach to support and enhance the capacity of its member states in the definition of drought management policies, specifically in relation to the role, availability, and supply of potential groundwater resources.  The project consists of four components.  The first, development and testing of a groundwater drought management plan for the Limpopo River Basin pilot areas, will test the application and replicability of methods of decreasing the vulnerability of local communities and GDEs to the effects of groundwater droughts, and to ensure that practical on-the-ground benefits accrue to local people from the project.  The second, regional groundwater drought management support, will provide tools for transboundary groundwater management, including hydrogeological maps and maps of groundwater vulnerability and water scarcity.  The third, establishment of the Groundwater Management Institute of Southern Africa (GMISA), will create an institution to increase knowledge of and capacity for groundwater management in SADC, in order to sustain the work of the project and maintain readiness to address future drought events.  The fourth, project management and administration, will provide maximum extemal support to the SADC Water Division.
